name: Tim
comment info: I have noticed that the  more miles drivers spend driving each passenger, they have less customers. I have also noted that there is an extremely high demand for drivers between 3-4 hours

comment info: I noticed that there are lots of request between 2 and 3 hours and about 5 miles travel. I wonder if this graph is representing individual Uber drivers or the company Uber drivers.

name: Charlotte Todd
comment info:
Uber and Lyft as well as other driving services that can be ordered by the click of a button have decreased drunk driving rates and helped those without cars be easily transported safely. However we cannot expect too much of these drivers. They are paid to go to a destination but getting from one drop off to another pick up is completely unaccounted for. 

In the graph it shows that the average driver would like about 3 rides an hour which is tricky with traffic and longer trips. Some that only get 2 requests take over 12 miles just to find the customer which isn't their fault. I don't think we should expect so much from this good service.

name: Mrs. Greene
comment info:
Hi all! Greetings from Mrs. Greene's 7th Grade Advanced ELA Classes in South Carolina.  

Some things we noticed: 
1. Drivers with 5 requests an hour cruise less than 4 miles.  
2. Some drivers spend more time cruising than fulfilling requests. 

Some things we wondered about include:  
1. Do the miles represented on the y axis represent the amount of miles covered? For example, a driver cruising a 10 mile radius is receiving less trip requests than a driver cruising a 4 mile area. If this is true, cruising a 4 mile radius is likely to yield the optimal trip requests per hour.  

2. Where does time of day fit into this data? Is this representative of a certain time period? How does rush hour or weekend boom affect the data?  

3. Does the rating of the driver have anything to do with amount of requests per hour?  

4. How is the optimal number of requests determined? 

5. Was there a significant difference between Uber data and Lyft data?  

Great headlines from students:  
"Cruising or Ubering; spending too much time waiting?" - Kaylee 
“Using gas or waiting for a task; Taking too much time waiting?” - Kaylee 
"Too Much Cruising, Not Enough Requesting" - Mariah 
"Cruising for Requests." - Tai’s

replies.comment info:
Welcome, @Mrs. Greene 7th Grade Advanced ELA class –

What great class noticings and wonderings!

Regarding your noticings, you are on to something by comparing requests to cruising miles, but we really don’t know much about time other than more requests and more cruising take more time than less of each.  

Regarding your wonderings, you’ll learn more about the 1,500 data points from the article that included this graph.  Later today, go back to the release and at the bottom you will see the Reveal with a free link to the article.
I’d like to turn around your wondering, “How is the optimal number of requests determined?”  What do you think?  If more requested trips make more money for the drivers and RideAustin, why won’t a greater number of requests be better?

Kaylee and Tai – What catchy headlines that capture the your main idea of the graph.  I wish I could give you a shout out online, but we’ve already gone to press.  Thank you for your creative headlines!

name: Moderator(DeAnna)
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph:  “Drive Less To Drive More” by Devyn of New Jersey and  “Cruising for Requests” by Liam of Washington.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, November 7 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graphs, and a few Stat Nuggets.

The next graph will be released tomorrow – Thursday, November 7, with moderation on Wednesday, November 13.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?”  The topic --  our presidents’ prior highest political or military positions.

You can see all of the released graphs on the “What’s Going On In This Graph?” homepage.  Or, go to our post “Looking for Graphs to Use in the Classroom? Here Are 34.” for an index by context and an index by graph type.

Signing off – Sharon Hessney of Boston, who takes Boston’s T (subway) and walks since car travel is so slow and parking is so expensive, and DeAnna McDonald of Tucson, Arizona, who carpools to work with whichever family member is willing.

replies.name: M

name: Sharon
comment info:
Is this a different kind of graph than “What’s Going On In This Graph?” has ever had?  Yes!  
This is an optimization graph.  Using 1,500 driver data points from RideAustin, this graph is used to find the optimal, or “best” combination of trip requests and “empty” cruising miles.  Once this combination is determined, the researcher used the history of the number of ride requests to determine how many drivers are needed on the road.  (Why do you think that the ride-hailing services don’t want too many or too few drivers?)

Think about what problem the researchers who collected this data are trying to solve.  Then, what do you notice?  What do you wonder?  What’s a catchy headline that captures the main idea of this graph?

name: Renata AOSE
comment info: In this graph are the statistics of the time cruising for requests versus the trip requests from drivers for ride services like Uber and Lyft. The optimal balance between both is shown by a line drawn around 3.4 trip requests and around 6 miles cruising for requests. I wonder why for the most part the time between the searching for requests and trip requests is pretty quick. This mainly might have to do with the popularity of ride-hailing services currently and the efficiency of using the apps as opposed to hailing a cab. Possible title: "Cruising for Cash with Uber and Lyft"

replies.name: M

comment info: This graph illustrates driving services like Uber and Lyft’s relationships between miles spent driving waiting for requests and trip requests per hour. I noticed that there is a clear relation in more requests per hour when the driver cruises less. I wonder why the trend follows this pattern since it is more logical to think that if the driver covers more areas, they would receive more requests. A possible headline could be “Drive Less To Drive More!”

replies.name: M

name: Lauren T
comment info:
This graph is about ride calling services such as Uber and Lyft. I noticed that the drivers take about 4 to 8 miles cruising for requests. They get around 2 to 4 requests per hour. Barely anyone drives for more than 9 miles for a request. I wonder how many rides a driver typically makes a day? I also wonder are the drivers in busy areas, is that why requests are common? 
Headline: Cruise Control

replies.comment info:
Welcome, @Lauren T --
This graph was used to determine how many ride-hailing vehicles are needed or are optimal (most trip requests per cruising miles).  What combination of number of trip requests and cruising miles is reasonable and optimal?  Based on this how could you calculate the optimal number of ride-hailing vehicles for Austin, Texas?
“Cruise Control” is a catchy headline.  Maybe tweak it to include your findings based on these questions.

name: Marina W
comment info: I notice that most drivers spend about 2 to 10 miles cruising for requests. I also notice that a large congregation of the blue dots are around 2-6 miles. I also notice that most drivers usually get 2-4 requests each hour. I also notice that the most favorable number of requests per driver each other is around 3 or 4.I wonder why the miles spent cruising for requests congregates around 2-8 miles. I also wonder why 3-4 number of requests per driver is the ideal amount. I also wonder why the miles spent cruising for requests doesn't exceeds 12 miles. I also wonder why there are rarely 6 requests per driver each other.In this graph, it shows the comparison between the miles spent cruising for requests and the trip requests per driver each other. In this graph, it also shows the optimal number of requests per driver each hour (which is around 3 or 4).A catchy headline for this graph is "Uber and Lyft are becoming more and more popular: here are some statistics."

replies.comment info:
Welcome, @Marina W --

Thank you for your noticings and wonderings.  

This graph is used to determine the best (optimal) number ride-hailing drivers for Austin, Texas.  Ask yourself, how many trip requests are typical for drivers?  And, with this number of trip requests, how many “empty” miles do these drivers have?  If you know the optimal number of trip requests, how could you estimate the number of drivers Austin needs?  

This answer could lead you to a catchy headline about the number of ride-hailing drivers.  Please share our ideas.

name: Brianna C
comment info:
This graph gives the statistics for uber and lyft drivers and the number of miles spent cruising for requests, and their trip requests per hour. The graph shows that most drivers spend 4 to 6 miles driving around looking for requests and they get 2 to 3 requests per hour. I wonder how many drivers are around in a specific area at each moment. I wonder this because usually, the most wait that a passenger has to endure when calling an uber or a lyft is around 12 minutes. I am somewhat surprised that drivers only get 2 to 3 requests per hour and also wonder how many hours a day they drive people or wait to drive people. 
Title: "Uber/Lift Cruise time and move time"

name: Graceanna
comment info:
Title: "Relation of Uber/Lyft Miles to Trip Requests" 
By the cluster of dots, it appears that most drivers spend 4 to 6 miles cruising for requests and they get 2 to 3 requests per hour. The reason the miles cruising number is probably higher is because drivers have to drive around and cover more areas to ensure that they get those requests. If drivers stay in one area, they are less likely to get requests, but if they drive around they can get a request from one location, and then move to another to get another request. However, it is interesting to see that the trend is not necessarily more mileage= more trip requests. I would assume that this is because if a driver drives around too much, they can miss requests while passing through an area.

replies.comment info:
Welcome, @Graceanna --

Thank you for all of your noticings.  

How about going one or two steps further?  The graph shows the optimal number of requests per driver each hour.  How do you think that number was determined?  If this number were true, then how would you determine the number of drivers needed?  What assumptions would you have to make to determine this number of drivers?

I hope you and the others online will share their ideas.

comment info: In this graph, I notice that the blue represents the number of driver requests each hour. replies.comment info:
Welcome, @Ava AOSE --

Thank you for your noticings and wonderings.
Your wonderings about the data are answered below the graph – in the source and the first paragraph.  It’s always important to know the source of the data and even check it.

You notice that “the blue represents the number of driver requests each hour.”You say that this means, if I may paraphrase you, when during the driver’s shift the driver has a trip request.  I would say it means the number of trip requests.  The label seems to be ambiguous.  Probably the x-axis should be “Number of trip requests per driver per hour.”For each shift, the data point is for the number of requests and the miles cruising.  Given this explanation, what do you notice and wonder?

name: Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of  “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Today’s graph shows about 1.5 million ride-hailing trips from the RideAustin (Texas) drivers – trip requests and miles spent cruising.  What’s the optimal number of requests per driver per hour?  Why is this the “best” number?

Ride-hailing trips are transportation, using services such as Uber and Lyft, that use online platforms to connect between passengers and drivers who may use their personal vehicles.
 
From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and  "What's going on in this graph?"  

Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas about the graph. 

On Thursday afternoon, we’ll reveal the article that included this graph and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.

The next “What’s Going On in This Graph?” will be released tomorrow -- Thursday, November 7 with moderation on Wednesday, November 13.  The topic – our president’s prior highest political or military position.

You wonder “why drivers travel so little distance I search for customers.”  Why do you think drivers have “empty” miles cruising for trip requests?  If there are too many empty miles, what could be done to reduce the number?  Think about the vertical line, which is the optimal number of requests per driver each hour.

name: Hammam
comment info:

replies.comment info:
HI, @Hammam --

Great wonder – “i wonder how much money they make in a regular day.”  I bet your could estimate a range of how much drivers earn.  

Here are some basic assumptions you would have to make. You could make more.
What is the average number of requests per hour?  How much does a driver earn per request?
How many miles do they cruise on average?  
How much does it cost to drive per mile?
How many hours do drivers work on a regular day?  

Based on your assumptions, how much do drivers make?  You may want to check online for driver’s earnings.  I believe that you are from Tumwater, near Olympia, WA, which I find online has both Uber and Lyft.  You may want to adjust this amount for our area.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Mrs. Lane, ELP Teacher --

You “wonder how many were Uber and how many were Lyft.”  Based on your wonder, I wonder if the data points for Uber and Lyft drivers are in different parts of the graph.  Or, if cars of different sizes are in different part other graph.  If either of these were true, then we could not generalize for all ride-hailing services.  Maybe one of the services has figured out a way to get more requests and cruise fewer miles.  That would be a winning combination!

name: Owl
comment info:
Having analyzed the scatter plot of the table, I did recognized that the dots represent a driver and the numbers for the Y axis is increasing by 2 to 12 and the X axis is going by 1 to 6. There seems to be no title for the graph and I recommend the title needs to be "Miles Cruised vs. Trip Request". The dots mostly commences at X axis 2 and graduates slowly to 4. There also is a line between 3 and 4 that seems to be a indicator per hour.
   The dots seem to curve into a waning crescent tilted a bit to the bottom. I wonder why the graph is doesn't have a title. Why does the dots seem to be more in the area of the X axis of 4 and increases more up at the 2 X axis and  8 Y axis.

replies.comment info:
Welcome, @Owl --
You ask, “Why does the dots seem to be more in the area of the X axis of 4 and increases more up at the 2 X axis and 8 Y axis.”  That’s the question we want to answer.  Why when drivers have fewer trip requests do they cruise more?  And why when they have more trip requests they cruise less?  The answers to these questions will help you find the meaning of the vertical line and understand the conclusions that can be derived from the graph.

name: john
comment info:
why use trip requests with the miles,
I noticed that all of the dots are in between 4 to 6 miles
and the title is how much gas is being used

replies.comment info:
HI, @john --

You wonder, “Why use trip requests with the miles?” You will find the answer to your question in the article that includes this graph.  We will give you its free link tomorrow in the Reveal that will appear at the end of this release.  

In short, this graph is used to determine the best or optimal number of ride-hailing vehicles.  The data is about vehicle “utilization” with trip requests when the vehicles are being used and cruising miles when they are not being used for trips.  

Why do you think the vertical line shows that about 3.4 trip requests per driver each hour is optimal?

name: Kya Montgomery
comment info: How to densely populated areas Affect the graph

replies.comment info:
HI, @Kya Montgomery --

Great wonder, Kya.  “How to densely populated areas affect the graph?”

This graph is based on data from Austin, Texas.  What do you think the graph would look like for Tumwater or even Olympia?  For New York City?   Would the relationship between trip requests and cruising mile per hour still be inverse – as the number of trip requests increase, the number of cruising miles decrease?  

Though you responded yesterday, I hope you and others with think about this relationship and share with us your thoughts.  Thank you.

name: Kathryn
comment info:
I notice that they spend more time cruising for requests than actually driving people or getting trip requests. There seems to be a negative correlation in the dots between miles used cruising for requests and trip requests per driver each hour. 
I wonder why there are more miles spent on waiting for requests than actual trip requests. Is it too expensive? Are there not enough drivers? Is there a limited amount of drivers? Are they competing with Uber and Lyft? I am curious to know their comparison and Uber and Lyft’s comparison.
This graph seems to be showing that there may or may not be more requests, but not enough drivers available or vice versa. A headline I would use would be: RideAustin ShareAustin

replies.comment info:
Hi, Kathryn --
Thank you for your noticings and wonderings.  
I’d like you to take another look at your first noticing:  “I notice that they spend more time cruising for requests than actually driving people or getting trip requests.” I’m not sure where you are seeing data on the amount of time cruising vs. driving.  I think the units for the x-axis is number of trip requests and the units for the y-axis is miles.
Regarding Uber and Lyft, we don’t know from this graph how they differ, but it would be very interesting to make subgroups for them and see if there is a difference.  Maybe one is better at getting drivers more trip requests with fewer cruising miles.
How do you interpret the vertical line?  How could this x-axis value be used to determine the optimal number of ride-hailing drivers?

name: Mackintosh Middle School Mathematicians
comment info:
Our wonderings include: 
-Why when cruising for more miles there a decline in requests for rides? Does this hold true in other areas? 

-How do densely populated areas affect the graph? 

-There is an optimal number of request for each driver, why is the optimal number of requests per drive where the highest density of dots and who/what decides what is the "optimal number of requests"? 

Headlines: 
Data show that for ride sharing services, staying in a smaller area provides greater benefits for drivers. 

Driving all around in my little Lyft; I see little Uber feeling super super; Wondering who is the best; I get another request

replies.comment info:
Welcome, @Mackintosh Middle School Mathematicians --
Thank you for your wonderings.  
You wonder “Why when cruising for more miles there a decline in requests for rides?” You may find your answer by examining the labels on the graph.  What is the relationship between number of trip requests per hour and cruising miles? 
You wonder “Does this hold true in other areas?”  In tomorrow’s Reveal which will appear at the bottom of this release, we give you the link to the article that included this graph.  There, you can read about whether the graph’s findings apply to areas other than Austin, Texas.
Your next wonder hits the issue that this graph addresses right on the head!  You wonder “why is the optimal number of requests per drive where the highest density of dots and who/what decides what is the optimal number of requests?” Maybe you can discuss this in your class and determine a reason.  This graph is solves an optimization problem – How many ride-hailing cars are needed in Austin?  If this graph determines the optimal number of requests per driver each hour, how could you determine the optimal number of drivers?
Love to have you report back to us on what you now conjecture.
